            if (this-or-that) {
       Gen.doNothing();

        Since:

      • ignoreReturnValue

        public static void ignoreReturnValue(Object obj)
        This method is used to self-document intentionally ignoring a method's return value. 
            Gen.ignoreReturnValue(Gen.now());
        Parameters:
        obj - any old object or null
        Since:
        1.0

      • length

        public static int length(Object obj)
        Null-safe way to determine the length of the given object.

        For Strings and other CharSequences, it's "str.length()".

        For arrays, it's "array.length".

        For anything unrecognized, it's zero. 

            Gen.getLength(null)    = 0
    Gen.getLength("")      = 0
    Gen.getLength("a")     = 1
    Gen.getLength([4,5,6]) = 3
        Parameters:
        obj - input object
        Returns:
        length of input object, or zero if null or unable to determine length
        Since:
        1.0

      • numElements

        public static int numElements(Object array)
        Null-safe way to determine the number of elements in an array, list, or collection.

        For arrays, it's "array.length".

        For Collections, it's "collection.size()".

        For anything unrecognized, it's zero. 

            Gen.numElements(null)               = 0
    Gen.numElements("hey")              = 0
    Gen.numElements(int[])              = 0
    Gen.numElements(byte[]{0x45})       = 1
    Gen.numElements(int[]{67, 22, -97}) = 3
        Since:
        1.0

      • sleep

        public static void sleep(long msec)
        Sleep for msec duration but do not throw an exception. 
            Gen.sleep(2)
    Gen.sleep(50)
    Gen.sleep(1000)
        Since:
        1.0

      • nullSafeClass

        public static Class nullSafeClass(Object object)
        Null-safe way to obtain the class of an object, or returns null if input is null.
        Since:
        1.0

      • nullSafeGet

        public static String nullSafeGet(Supplier<String> messageSupplier)
        Null-safe way to object the string supplied by the messageSupplier.
        Parameters:
        messageSupplier - functional interface that supplies the needed string
        Returns:
        text from the messageSupplier, or null if it is null

      • getItem

        public static Object getItem(Object[] objs,
                             int index,
                             Object def)
        Safely retrieve an item from an array of objects.

        If the index is out of range, or the object is null, then simply return the passed-in default value. 

            final Object[] items = {"hey", 1, false};
    Gen.getItem(null, 0, null)  = null
    Gen.getItem(null, 0, "foo") = "foo"
    Gen.getItem(items, 0, null) = "zero"
    Gen.getItem(items, 1, null) = 1
    Gen.getItem(items, 2, null) = false
    Gen.getItem(items, 3, null) = null
        Since:
        1.0

      • getArg

        public static String getArg(String[] args,
                            int index)
        Safely retrieve an item from an array of strings.

        If the argument is null or the index is out of range, then an empty string is returned. 

            final String[] args = {"zero", "one", "two"};
    Gen.getArg(null, 0)  = ""
    Gen.getArg(args, -1) = ""
    Gen.getArg(args, 0)  = "zero"
    Gen.getArg(args, 1)  = "one"
    Gen.getArg(args, 2)  = "two"
    Gen.getArg(args, 3)  = ""
        Since:
        1.0

      • getField

        public static String getField(String input,
                              int num)
        Safely retrieve a field from inside a string.

        Fields are separated by one or more spaces; multiple spaces between items is acceptable.

        If the argument is null or the index is out of range, then an empty string is returned.

        Indexes are numbered starting at one. 

            Gen.getField(null, 0)                    = ""
    Gen.getField("one two three", -1)        = ""
    Gen.getField("one two three", 0)         = ""
    Gen.getField("one two three", 1)         = "one"
    Gen.getField("one two three", 2)         = "two"
    Gen.getField("one two three", 3)         = "three"
    Gen.getField("one two three", 4)         = ""
    Gen.getField(" one   two  three ", 2)    = "two"
        Parameters:
        num - num >= 1
        Since:
        1.0

      • getField

        public static String getField(String input,
                              int num,
                              String separator)
        Safely retrieve a field from inside a string.

        Fields are separated by one or more of "separators"; multiple separators between items is acceptable.

        If the argument is null or the index is out of range, then an empty string is returned.

        Indexes are numbered starting at one. 

            Gen.getField(null, 0)                    = ""
    Gen.getField("one;two;three", -1, ";")   = ""
    Gen.getField("one;two;three", 0, ";")    = ""
    Gen.getField("one-two-three", 1, "-")    = "one"
    Gen.getField("one:two:three", 2, ":")    = "two"
    Gen.getField("one#two#three", 3, "#")    = "three"
    Gen.getField("one#two#three", 4, "#")    = ""
    Gen.getField("one##three", 3, "#")       = "three"
        Since:
        1.0

      • getCurrentMethodName

        public static String getCurrentMethodName()
        Call this method in this manner: 
            final String methodName = Gen.getCurrentMethodName();

        See: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/442747/getting-the-name-of-the-currently-executing-method

        Returns:
        name of the currently executing method, used for debugging purposes
        Since:
        1.0

      • getCurrentMethodNameLambda

        @Deprecated
public static String getCurrentMethodNameLambda()
        Deprecated. only works in the "log" example show above
        This method MUST be called using a lambda, otherwise it will return an incorrect method name: 
            log.trace("{}", Gen::getCurrentMethodNameLambda);
        Returns:
        name of the currently executing method, used for debugging purposes
        Since:
        1.0
